Milt- 
        I cannot check the Token_kenkyu list remotely, I wonder if 
=
you will see the following gets to the approppriate list?

All- 
        So=
meone asked about matching a single menuki showing a brush 
and inkstone. W=
hile I think trying to find the needle in the haystack 
would be easier, I =
can at least help point you toward what to look 
for.

        There are tw=
o possible themes referred to with these items; 
one is Sugarawa Michizane =
and the other is Tanabata. Since I can't 
remember who posted the query I w=
ill assume you do not instantly 
recognize these.

        Sugawara Michiza=
ne was a famous scholar, courtier and 
minister who ran afoul of certain me=
mbers of the Fujiwara who smeared 
his name and turned the Emperor agaisnt =
him. He was known to study 
under the Plum trees in his garden. When he was=
 to leave for exile in 
Kyushu, he penned a now famous poem to his trees en=
treating them to 
send their sweet Frangrance to him though he be far away.=
 At which 
point one of the trees uprooted and flew off to Kyushu and his p=
lace 
of exile. So if you see plum blossoms this is the theme, and your 
ma=
tch might be a scroll with bits of the poem on it, or Michizane 
riding an =
Ox, or a simple plum branch.

        Tanabata is celebrated on the 7th day=
 of the 7th month, in 
China it is called Kikoden (Japanese reading here). =
The lord of the 
heavens allowed his daughter to marry a simple shepard but=
 she 
behaved so badly on the wedding day that he forced them to live on 
o=
pposites sides of the Milky Way. Once a year they are allowed to see 
each =
other when the Ama no Gawa (River of Heaven) Is bridged by a 
murder of cro=
ws. The rest of the year, she spends pining to see her 
husband and weaving=
, so is known as Ori-Hime,"Ori" means to weave. In 
the Chinese tradition f=
resh inkstones were laid outside on "kuzu" 
leaves, on top of these were la=
id bunches of Yam leaves to "catch the 
dew". On the day of the festival ce=
lebrants would write their wishes 
with the dewdrops from the river of heav=
en.According to Joly 
this "emblematic representation of the Tanabata festi=
val was a 
familiar theme of tsuba decoration by the Umetada."

        Sin=
ce Ori-hime spends all year wishing to see her husband, 
this is the one da=
y all year when wishes are fulfilled. So the custom 
is to write your wishe=
s on colored strips of paper, since this is a 
rather romantic story it is =
also a day for romance and love poems in 
Japan. If along with the inkstone=
 and brushes you see leaves, strips 
of paper or a (weaving) shuttle then y=
our theme is Tanabata.

        As was suggested simple kanji might be a go=
od match though I 
couldn't find them paired "as a theme", also an ink well=
 with it's 
lid would be good. According to the Tsuba Gadai Jiten, These ev=
eryday 
items are indespensable, ink and brush are inseperable. So I guess =

they symbolize a well ordered world, a well rounded gentlemen=A1=C4

Hopin=
g this helps, 
-t
